intro: Calamintha nepalensis, commonly known as Nepal mint, is a perennial herb native to the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by aromatic leaves and square stems. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and features opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a fragrant, mint-like aroma. Its small, tubular flowers are usually violet or blue, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Calamintha nepalensis is often used in traditional medicine for its purported cooling and digestive properties.
